Title:
The effect of data manipulating on the utility of
mitochondrial genome to systematic entomology: a case study of
Holometabola
Keywords:
data treatment, mitochondrial genome, Holometabola,
phylogeny
Abstract:
Mitochondrial genome is one of the most widely used marker
for phylogenetic analysis. Compared to larger genome data, mitochondrial
genome is less expensive and more conveniently obtained. However, some
features like compositional bias and accelerated evolutionary rate
reduce the effectiveness of mitochondrial genome to insect phylogeny. In
this paper, we implemented different data manipulating strategies and
distinct substitution models to the phylogenetic inference of
Holometabola. The result showed that the Degen-coding scheme and the
site-heterogeneous CAT model could better correct for some systematic
errors and reconstruct a reasonable phylogeny of Holometabola. The
monophyly of major supraordinal clades and a monophyletic Holometabola
were supported. This paper illustrates the relative strengths and
shortcomings of the mitochondrial genome data for assessing the
challenging problem of higher-level insect phylogenetics, and thereby
provides useful pointers for future utilities of this type of data.
